item.title: Screening distances
item.description: According to Federal Transportation Administration (FTA) guidelines Schools are land areas that warrant a ‘Detailed Noise Analysis’ for yards or shops similar to a rail yard, yet GoTriangle did not conduct any noise analysis at Creekside Elementary. GoTriangle noted in a noise and vibration report that schools are noise-sensitive land use areas. Specifically, ‘a maintenance facility near a school’ (p. 33) is one location recommended for a ‘Detailed Noise Analysis’ The ‘screening distance for noise assessments’ at a school is 1,000 feet for unobstructed distances 650 feet for obstructed distances (‘with intervening buildings’) Guidelines for evaluating the noise impact of a maintenance facility near a school may specify certain screening distances to select schools, but they are ‘NOT a substitute for case- and site-specific evaluation of potential risks and hazards’.

item.title: Public Health
item.description: Children spend a large part of their day at school. Understanding any increases in the noise footprint at Creekside Elementary school caused by the railyard operation maintenance facility (ROMF) is important. A growing body of evidence points towards an association between chronic environmental noise exposure (including noise from rail) and declines in a child’s cognitive performance. To acheive this end, environmental noise is not at levels that cause hearing loss.
